Hannah Haberkern

Welcome to my personal website.

I'm a neuroscientist studying visually guided navigation.
I also enjoy sewing, gardening and programming.
Or I like to simply look at plants and animals.

Jedes Bildnis ist eine Sünde. Es ist genau das Gegenteil von Liebe [...] Wenn man einen Menschen liebt, so läßt man ihm doch jede Möglichkeit offen und ist trotz allen Erinnerungen einfach bereit, zu staunen, immer wieder zu staunen, wie anders er ist, wie verschiedenartig und nicht einfach so, nicht ein fertiges Bildnis [...]

- Max Frisch, Stiller

About Me

Hi, I'm Hannah. I'm a neuroscientist interested in understanding animal behavior, in particular in the context of navigation. If I'm not in the lab or analysing data, I like to sew, program, garden or observe animals.

More about me

My CV

Research

I'm currently working as postdoctoral associate in Vivek Jayaraman's lab at Janelia. I am interested in understanding how animals navigate through space. Currently I invstigate how visually guided navigation in walking fruit flies can change based on past experiences. Previous projects involved different aspects of navigation in adult and larval fruit flies and crickets.

Research interests

Project descriptions

(Data) Visualisation

One of my favorite parts of quantitatively studying behavior is to come up with ways to visualise the measured variables. In my experience, finding the "right" way of looking at the data often leads to better understanding of what is going on.

Visualising behavior

Sewing

I greatly enjoy designing and sewing clothes and other objects made from fabric. I learned how to sew from my mother and grandmother and many of my favourite childhood memories evolve around this activity. These days sewing serves as a compensatory activity to research — as a creative outlet and by making me feel productive.
